case_vignette: A pregnant woman gives birth to her 1st child at the family farm. After delivery, the assisting midwife notices a triangular defect in the lower anterior abdominal wall of the baby. She clamps the umbilical cord with a cloth and urges the family to seek immediate medical care at the nearest hospital. Upon admission, the attending pediatrician further notices an open bladder plate with an exposed urethra, a low set umbilicus, an anteriorly displaced anus, and an inguinal hernia. No omphalocele is noted. The external genitalia is also affected. On physical exam, a shortened penis with a pronounced upward curvature and the urethral opening along the dorsal surface are also noted.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm not feeling anything myself, but my newborn baby has a kind of triangle-shaped opening on the lower belly, right where the stomach meets the legs.
Thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me the baby's age and sex?
My baby is a newborn and a boy.
Thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me if the baby has any other symptoms or if this is the only symptom you're aware of?
He also has what looks like an open area on his lower belly where I can see part of the inside, his belly button seems to be lower than usual, and his bottom is not in the right place.
Thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me if the baby has any medical history or if this is the first time you've noticed these symptoms?
This is the first time, he was just born.
Thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me if the baby has any family history of similar conditions?
I'm not sure; this is my first baby, and I haven't heard of anyone in the family having something like this.

Thank you for sharing that information. Based on the symptoms you've described, it's possible that your baby may have a condition called "umbilical hernia." An umbilical hernia occurs when the umbilical cord and surrounding tissue protrude through a small opening in the abdominal wall. This can cause a bulge or triangle-shaped opening on the lower belly, as well as a lower belly button and misplaced bottom. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.

Final Diagnosis: Umbilical Hernia.
